comments.commentBody: And tomorrow, Jeb! will elaborate, exasperatedly: " Stuff happens, for crying out loud!"

It's not a democracy. It's a theocracy, with a monarch elected by hierarchs, who can promulgate laws for all the members. If you don't believe that, you are not a Roman Catholic. You can leave, but if you do, you will suffer the torments of hell. This institution is about 10 times older than the USA. I don't belong to it and I don't pay attention to its dogmas. I also don't have any truck with the Great Flying Spaghetti Monster.

If there was real support perhaps it would be more evident. Fortunately for gays et al much of the planet is inhabited by God fearing folk who are content to congregate, partake of the sacraments and live their lives in contentment with the hope of salvation. As Christians they define define acceptable conduct differently than a few exceptionally loud members by name only. Wail and gnash teeth all you want. Total acceptance of abortion and homosexuality will remain beyond reach.

They are brainwashed by the church dogma. I was raised a Catholic; baptized, first communioned and confirmed. Married in a Catholic church. I have renounced all of their teachings since I have matured. I don't believe any institution has the right to dictate to me how many children I have or how I raise them. I don't believe they have the right to dictate to me that I remain in an abusive marriage because divorce is against biblical teachings. That I can't marry one outside my faith, that if my children are not baptized they will be condemned in death. My husband and I have 5 children. None are religious. All are good, moral people. None could care less about gay marriage or feel that it has any impact whatsoever on their heterosexual marriages or relationships. Kim Davis used religion to justify her bigotry. Had she said that she couldn't support gay marriage because she finds it "icky" she would have been laughed out of her job or told to either perform her duties or resign. Fascism has indeed come to our country and it is wrapped  in the flag carrying the bible just as foretold. Sadly the ignorant among us are too blind to see. This is why Trump is leading in the polls. The fools can't see the manipulation of Fascism; wrapping itself in the flag and carrying the cross. We are doomed.

Yes, the Pope is Catholic--a patriarchal institution that excludes women and self-accepting gay people from its governance. To watch hundreds of thousands flock to catch a glimpse of this head of a misogynistic, homophobic institution has been depressing. We read that American Catholics reject their church's teaching on birth control and support same-sex marriage in numbers greater than most Christian sects. But they continue to let their leaders be men who do all in their power to thwart reproductive and LGBT rights. When will Catholics grow up and take charge of their own church?
What, deflecting Bush's own words back onto himself?

Do you suppose that the pope happened to mention to Ms. Davis that according to the words of Jesus Christ as reported in the tenth chapter of Mark, her current cohabitation is actually a cardinal sin, one even forbidden by the Seventh of the Ten Commandments:  Adultery, anyone?

Notice, though, that many religious conservatives nowadays disavow the New Testament, in favor of the Old Testament. Severe punishments doled out by a vengeful, bigoted God comports more directly with their world views. So, you are right: Jesus, if here today, would not recognize what he sees as anything close to what he preached.

I don't seriously care what any religious person says. Read the New Testament and read what Jesus preached. He preached of inclusiveness and love and forgiveness, not the hatred and bigotry being said by "Christians." Jesus would abhor the massive wealth of the Catholic Church and redistribute it to the poor.
If Jesus were here today he would not recognize "Christianity" as being anything like what he taught when he was here first.
The Pope could have met with someone dedicated to traditional marriage other than this particular voguing diva of low brow right wing media fame.

.
Yes, Kiki. The runner who touches home plate unmolested is presumed to have scored a run; that is, the home-plate umpire is obligated to give the safe signal. Only by getting an umpire to rule the runner to be out at 3d can the run be negated.

Same thing for a flyout-double play with one out, if a runner scores without having tagged up.

Dan got it really close to precise, and I don't know what Kiki's link says, but I did want to supplement Dan's description for the sake of completeness:

Umpires may be called upon to call 4 outs in an inning because of one or more runners not tagging up, it's true; but the same would happen if a runner DID tag up but left the base too early. THAT call must be made by the umpire assigned to the base which the runner improperly ran from.

I think the no-tagging-up or tagging-but-leaving-too-soon (or some combination) scenarios would cover any quadruple play.

BUT, I wonder if this would count as well? 2 or 3 on, none out. Count is 0-2. Batter attempts a bunt at a ball below his knees, and misses, but also pulls his bat back. Umpire must rule on whether it was a swing; and if it was a swing, the umpire signals for an out. But the catcher drops the ball OR fails to catch it before it hits the ground, so the ball is live and every batter/runner is free to run. If the defense gets 2 lead runners out, and the batter reaches first, the batter is entitled to that base; but if the batter/runner ROUNDS 1st, he can be tagged out. 4 outs.
Thanks, Wilber, for the on-the-scene analysis.   Barleycorn does help, doesn't it!

http://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Quadruple_play

The situation Dan describes is same as the link, more or less. AFAIK, it's never happened. You could say it's more "hypothetical" than "super-rare," and I guess the "lore" in the clue buys a little wiggle room. Worth noting, only three outs are recorded; never are four outs officially called. (The internet provides a few other examples of so-called quadruple plays, but those are just triple plays where another runner could have been out if the inning continued -- but when the third out is made, the inning is done.)

Earlier this week my son, Donovan, had asked about a situation that truly is a "super-rare feat," and one that actually happened. He googled it up to find that twice in MLB history pitchers have lost games while throwing no-hitters (Ken Johnson for the Colt .45s in 1964, and Steve Barber/Stu Miller for the Orioles in 1967). (Three other times pitches went 8 innings in a no-hit loss, but that doesn't count for an official no-hitter.)
Dan - You've got it!  The fourth out is the appeal play to third base to void the run because the runner left third base without tagging up.

Certainly.  And we should forget -- I can't think of a single law we ought to have.  We law-abiding people would be freed at last, to massacre everyone we think looks dangerous -- and take other people's bank accounts, and remove (not "steal", it would be against no law) stuff from stores, and all the other things we would never do only (?) because there are laws against them.
cameronj666, that is the debate gun control advocates are having.  The NRA and its followers are not having that debate.

.
It's certainly not the same thing as a quadruple play, but I was at a game in 1987 or so in which the defense tried to get a fourth out.

On a fly ball with one out, the runners all tagged up. One crossed home plate safely but the catcher then threw out another runner who had fallen and was not in contact with any base. Hence, 3 outs (one out before the play, one out on the catch, and the tag on the runner who fell). But the defense didn't leave the field; the pitcher got the ball, stepped on the rubber, stepped off the rubber, and threw to 3rd for the "appeal play" in an effort to nullify the run.

The 3rd base umpire signaled safe.

I was also at a game where the pitcher couldn't get the ball out of his glove on a grounder back to the mound, so he threw his glove to first with the ball in it. For some reason, this doesn't violate the rule against throwing equipment during a live play, so the batter/runner (who didn't get to 1st in time) was called out as soon as the umpire verified that the ball was in the thrown glove.
Los frijoles have been speeled.  The movie was Viva Max (1969).  Sign/Countersign.  John Wayne/John Avatar stars of The Alamo (1960) which was spoofed in Viva Max.

Martin, listening to old-time radio was not a misspent activity. Radio stimulated the imagination. TV, on the other hand, stifled it and I am guilty of misspending my youth on TV after enhancing it with radio, though early TV had some great programs.

.
Martin,

It's been 3 weeks since I told the stories about who admired Henry Ford, and who gave Ford a medal he would not return even after WWII began. A woman who is about 80 said she never knew why her father always bought Chevrolets and refused to buy Fords.

I opined about the first Henry Ford here http://wordplay.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/07/27/fast-work/#permid=37 and in an unfortunate number of unfortunately-long submissions on the same blog.

I would say though that Henry Ford II was a terrific corporate leader and that he really re-shaped the company. I'm not going to begrudge anyone purchasing Fords today. I also don't begrudge the purchase of Volkswagens, unless the product is of the "quality" described by JFC.

I was just gesturing toward the origin of the name. Ford's Model T was the "People's Car" because it was affordable. Germany was thought to need an affordable automobile to get the economy moving again. Hence, "Volkswagen", or Folks' Car a/k/a the People's Car.

My parents have bought one Ford and no Volkswagens.
Martin, I was at a disadvantage with this puzzle. I once owned a Rabbit and when I saw LE, I was sure it was LEMON.
Read the recipe. It clearly says to cut the sausage into round pieces once you cook it.
Calories are not the only issue with sodas, carbonated drinks also have been linked to demineralization, which can also be very destructive.
How do you feel when someone uses a car to run into a crowd? Or uses a knife on a subway?

Guns should require licensing, registration, and proof of insurance. We require those things for car and home ownership; it's ridiculous that a deadly weapon shouldn't require the same (at minimum).

Likewise, nowhere in the Second Amendment does it state that citizens should be able to hoard weapons, or that the average citizen should be able to own certain weapons with high capacity magazines.
North Carolina already has one. It takes from 30-90 days for a background check before you can get a permit to purchase a firearm.

Pro gun people throw out the mental illness argument but I have to ask which of us hasn't been in a situation where someone had a loud disagreement, got angry, threatened, committed a violent act, etc.  Guns are being used by people who pass for normal as well as the aggrieved mourner. What's wrong with having a uniform permitting process --similar to licensing for cars--as a first step to start to control the madness?

Neither the self-defence argument under the second amendment to the US constitution nor alibis like weak mental state should blind the political class from the grim reality of gun related violence on streets and school/college premises. It's time the farce of the  powerful American rifles association,  it's funded lobbying, and intoxicating obsession with gun culture promotion be exposed and confronted by enacting a more balanced and socially sensitive gun control legislation with social peace and the interests of progeny in mind.
Yes, he is inarticulate. And when he does manage to  get a complete sentence together,, the content is inane.  He is a¨real nowhere man.¨
And that takes a lot to out stupid George.
Shrub & Shrug.
Jeb! is sounding stupider every day, and stupider than his brother.
I know, which is why I figured a comment about who Ned Land was would be more accessible than a reply.
Guns do not kill people. States violence kills. People kill. Evil kills.

The statistics are common:
1. 300,000,000 guns in the U.S.
2. They are owned by roughly 96,518,700 Americans
3. Ownership isn't even: only 5% of people in Delaware own a gun
4. 60% of Alaskans own a gun
5. Americans spend billions a year to pay the cost of gun violence
6. 1,396,733 died in all our wars, to date
7. 1,516,863 have died from gun violence; over 10,000 more every year

And so?

You see, most of us reading about the issue believe that guns kill people and that you can change that if you have controls on guns, ammunition, training, etc., as we do for drugs, cars, alcohol, boating, outdoor fires, fishing, hunting driving, and pretty much every other responsibility citizens enjoy.

Most gun owners don't believe guns kill people. And Congress cares more about what gun owners think.

So get used to gun violence. It's likely to stay this way for a very, very long time. Fact is, some gun owners guarantee you that if you try to change it they'll visit gun violence on you for your efforts.
.

That is a big issue for low income kids. Many have never been to a dentist and by the time they're in grammar school they have serious dental problems with substantial pain which obviously makes learning much more difficult.

And we haven't mentioned any of the other health and psychological problems caused by the terrible American diet these to which kids are subjected. Yes, bad diet causes emotional and psychological problems for more than a few.

Something that is not mentioned very often in the discussion about sweetened carbonated drinks is tooth decay. Poor dental health can be crippling. Pain, inability to chew, and chronic infection can be crippling.

The sugar promotes it, and the acidity of the carbonation enhances it.

It would be interesting to see any results from a long term study that would correlate any decrease in soda consumption with any decrease in tooth decay, particularly among children and teen agers who generally don't have any control over the dental care they receive.

My husband was a dentist and there were two classes of patients he spotted right away, those few whose parents ran a corner store where the kids had a steady candy diet, and those who drink a lot of soda or use 2 or more teaspoons of sugar in the many cups of tea or coffee they drink a day.

Lower consumption of soda may result in less dental disease, particularly among those who can least afford dental care.

For every shooting tragedy, there's a number of traumatized people left behind. They too are victims of the shooter. The ones that knew the murdered as a daughter, son, mother, father, brother, sister, aunt, uncle, grandparent, neighbor, work colleague, student, teacher, friend. And all of us who didn't know those who ere shot are also traumatized. The message gets reinforced that there are no more publicly safe places. I hope the NYTimes will investigate the NRA. I want to know who the enablers are, the funders, the manufacturers, the investors, the PR reps.  Then I want the gun sellers to be exposed. It's time they get seen for who they are and what they are: merchants of death.

You clearly have not been to Southern California where the tap water tastes like a mysterious concoction of stale chemicals. Every time I go visit relatives there, the first thing I do is to go to a store and buy a big case of bottled water to enjoy during my stay.

While it is a good sign that consumers are making healthier choices, I find it a little disconcerting that packaged water is becoming so pervasive.  In western countries clean water is literally available on tap.  Shouldn't communities be looking to make water more readily available and convenient instead of increasing pollution and waste through packaging and transporting it?
Cowardice reigns supreme.
